thread.title: Manchester United legend Dwight Yorke denied entry to US due to Iranian passport stamp
thread.title_full: Manchester United legend Dwight Yorke denied entry to US due to Iranian passport stamp

title: Manchester United legend Dwight Yorke denied entry to US due to Iranian passport stamp
text:
Manchester United legend Dwight Yorke denied entry to US due to Iranian passport stamp Last updated 15:01, February 18 2017 GETTY IMAGES 
Dwight Yorke was denied entry to the US because he played a charity game in Tehran. 
Manchester United ambassador Dwight Yorke has been denied entry into the United State because of an Iranian stamp in his passport. 
Yorke, who had worked the previous day for BeIN Sports as a pundit on United's Europa League win over French club St Etienne, said he was trying to return to his home in the Caribbean, via Miami, from Qatar. 
"I couldn't quite believe what was happening. I have lost count of the number of times I have been to America, I love the country, yet I was being made to feel like a criminal," he told The Sun . 
"I had bought my ticket and checked in and was about to get on the flight when I was stopped by two officials. 
READ MORE: * Footballer defends fakery 
"I thought 'what is happening here?'. They told me there was a visa problem and a red flag had come up against my name because of an Iranian stamp in my passport. 
"I went there to play in a legends match to open a stadium and didn't even stay overnight." 
The Iranian stamp in Yorke's passport related to him playing in a charity match in Tehran, in 2015. 
That charity match in Tehran featured Yorke on a World Stars team that also included Luis Figo, Roberto Carlos, Fabio Cannavaro, Marcel Desailly and Edgar Davids. 
Yorke was told by officials that if he boarded the flight from Qatar to Miami, he would be sent back to Qatar from the US. Ad Feedback 
"I tried to explain I didn't even live in Qatar and was just trying to get to my home in the Caribbean." 
US President Donald Trump had issued an executive order banning travellers from seven Muslim-majority countries, including Iran, from entering the US for 90 days. 
The ban has since been suspended in a series of court rulings for constitutional reasons but Yorke still claims to have been prevented from entering the country. - AAP
